entries.meaning: A photograph, especially one taken quickly or in a sudden moment of opportunity.
examples: He carried a snapshot of his daughter.

entries.meaning: A glimpse of something; a portrayal of something at a moment in time.
examples: The article offered a snapshot of life in that region.

entries.meaning: (computing) A file or set of files captured at a particular time, often capable of being reloaded to restore the earlier state.
examples: This game is so hard that I find myself taking a snapshot every few seconds in case I get killed.

entries.meaning: (soccer) A quick, unplanned or unexpected shot.
(firearms) A quick offhand shot, made without deliberately taking aim over the sights.
examples: How quick the eye and hand to catch him [the ruffed grouse] when he rises from the underbrush and is out of sight in the wood before the untrained sportsman stops him with what is little more than a snapshot, so instantaneously must all be done!

verbs.description: snapshot (third-person singular simple present snapshots, present participle snapshotting, simple past and past participle snapshotted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To capture the state of, in a snapshot.
examples: Filer appliances also offer programmatic snapshotting and cloning at the block-level or file system-level.
